classes is when the processor pauses the execution of a task to execute another
task before um switching back now a computer can do this very efficiently
the human brain on the other hand cannot so every time that you do a context switch not only are you losing focus but

professor at the University of North Carolina uh program grammar takes between 10 to 15 minutes to start
editing code after resuming work from an interruption an uninterrupted task is
estimated to take twice as long and contain twice as many errors as uninterrupted tasks and a programmer is

now back to your student days if you thought that 90% of your day as a software engineer would be you hunched

uh what I want to talk about here is realizing that technical debt might be a necessary evil now when I first started
off as an engineer I had very strong opinions on Tech Deb I even remember
expressing my opinion very strongly in an interview and needless to say I didn't get the job my naive undergrad
version thought that um like you know debt in general carries a very negative connotation so I assumed that the same
held true for Tech debt as well now Tech debt is is basically the cost of getting
it done as opposed to doing it right it includes things like a last minute hacky fix poor or a complete lack of
documentation a poor testing Suite among other things you can think of tech tech
as the number of to-dos in your code base similar to context switching it's
unrealistic to expect not to have any Tech debt there's definitely circumstances where it's necessary to
take on this debt but there's two things that I like to keep in mind with regards to Tech debt number one taking it on
should be a conscious decision it needs to be intentional and secondly you need to be cognizant enough to pay it off in
a timely manner accumulating Tech Deb can lead to a slow down in development work or Worse having to rewrite the
entire application so what do you do when you
get to the fork in the road where you have a choice between getting it done versus doing it right first and this
ties into to my earlier point about understanding the value that you're bringing to the business be very clear
on what's important is getting the future out on time more important or is rolling it out
with little to no issues more important this is going to determine whether you decide to take on Tech debt get Buy in
from senior Engineers leverage their experience and expertise they might be able to provide alternatives to taking
on Tech Deb secondly if you do take on Tech de remember to pay it off and that
doesn't mean just making a mental note of it that means that you includeed as a part of your backlog if you have a
project like completion checklist include it as part of your project completion criteria your project isn't
complete until you've paid off Tech debt don't treat working on Tech debt like a
second class citizen um this is as important as any other task in your backlog working on improving
documentation or your test we doesn't make you any less of an engineer appreciate and acknowledge team members
that work on paying down Tech debt we we have a ritual in our team where every week we give a shout out to any engineer
who paid off some sort of tech debt don't play the blame blame game and don't point fingers if you've taken on
Tech de own up to it if you want your Tech de to be taken seriously you need to quantify it as well what did that
lack of a test Suite result in for the business maybe the missing test Suite caused you to roll out a feature one
week later than expected that's you quantifying your Tech de was it a loss
of Revenue because you rolled out a faulty feature if so how much revenue next share your knowledge if
you've paid off Tech de and you've noticed some consistent thems in the tech de that you've paid off share your
learnings with your team to prevent future occurrences of the same issue on a similar note establish coding
standards a lot of the times just because there's no standards established there there's no standards that are
established there's room for sloppy execution so it's establish these standards and make sure that they're
continue to be enforced through code reviews for example lastly one of the trickiest
parts about tech debt is that it can be this very vicious cycle you have a badly
written application but it works so no one bothers to do a refactor why fix it if it's not broken right additionally a
refactor might also not sound as appealing from a business value perspective and there's no denying that
refactors definitely carry a lot of risk as well if it's a choice between developing a new feature versus a refactor the forer
will most likely be given preference now over time that battery written
application keeps getting bigger so the tech that keeps on increasing until you get to the point where it's actually
become difficult to add to the application just because of how badly written it is this is that that point of
no return that you want to avoid the solution here is to do and prioritize
refactor before your application gets to this point of no
return so to recap these are the key takeaways from this session um embracing
the ambiguity within your role understanding your project inside and out and its value to the business
acknowledging that project planning is complex and that nothing is set in stone um practicing clear effective and
efficient communication acknowledging that context switching is an unfortunate but inevitable part of your role and
lastly real realizing that technical debt might be unnecessary evil but yeah that brings me to the end
